module.name: requirement_identification_and_version
module.purpose:
This part of ISO 10303 specifies an application module for the representation of the data that identify a requirement and versions of requirements.
The concept of a "requirement", in this context, relates chiefly to the exchange and sharing of data between requirements engineering applications such as those used in the systems engineering and related industrial domains.
The second edition of this part of ISO 10303 incorporates the modifications to the first edition listed below.
The following ARM EXPRESS declarations and interface specifications have been removed:
USE FROM Product_identification_arm;
USE FROM Product_version_arm.
In addition, modifications have been made to the MIM schema and the EXPRESS-G diagrams to reflect and be consistent with the modifications of the ARM.
The third edition of this part of ISO 10303 incorporates the modifications to the second edition listed below.
No ARM EXPRESS declarations and interface specifications have been modified.
In addition, modifications have been made to the mapping specification, the MIM schema and the EXPRESS-G diagrams to reflect and be consistent with the ARM.
The USE FROM product_definition_schema has been extended to include product_category and product_related_product_category

inscope.li: representation of the data that identify a requirement and its versions;
items within the scope of application module Product version relationship, ISO/TS 10303-1020.

outscope.li: representation of any use of a requirement.

uof.name: Requirement
uof.description: The Requirement UoF specifies the data type needed to represent the data that identify a requirement.

uof.name: Requirement_Version
uof.description: The Requirement_Version specifies the data type needed to represent the data that identify a version of requirement.

uof.name: Requirement_Version_Relationship
uof.description: The Requirement_Version_Relationship UoF specifies the data type needed to represent a sequential relationship between two versions of a relationship.
